1.brief: perhaps properly, to arrange; but used figuratively (of words), to speak; rarely (in a destructive sense) to subdue
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
near, with or among; often in general, to
a pasture (i.e. open field, whither cattle are driven); by implication, a desert; also speech (including its organs)
a tent (as clearly conspicuous from a distance)

properly, an appointment, i.e. a fixed time or season; specifically, a festival; conventionally ayear; by implication, an assembly (as convened for a definite purpose); technically the congregation; by extension, the place of meeting; also a signal (as appointed beforehand)
properly, united, i.e. one; or (as an ordinal) first
the new moon; by implication, a month
properly, double, i.e. second; also adverbially, again
a year (as a revolution of time)
properly, double, i.e. second; also adverbially, again
to go (causatively, bring) out, in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively, direct and proxim.
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
Mitsrajim, i.e. Upper and Lower Egypt

2.brief: to lift, in a great variety of applications, literal and figurative, absolute and relative
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
the head (as most easily shaken), whether literal or figurative (in many applications, of place, time, rank, itc.)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
a stated assemblage (specifically, a concourse, or generally, a family or crowd)
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity
a family, i.e. circle of relatives; figuratively, a class (of persons), a species (of animals) or sort (of things); by extension a tribe or people
a house (in the greatest variation of applications, especially family, etc.)
father, in a literal and immediate, or figurative and remote application
a number, definite (arithmetical) or indefinite (large, innumerable; small, a few); also (abstractly) narration
an appellation, as amark or memorial of individuality; by implication honor, authority, character
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
properly, remembered, i.e. a male (of man or animals, as being the most noteworthy sex)
a skull (as round); by implication, a head (in enumeration of persons)

to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
